description: With a sculpture garden, performance art in the attic and live music in the bowels of The Steamship, built in the heart of Docklands 1885, the resident artists show how the area has transformed and how they've transformed the former pub.

events.name: The Story Kitchen
events.notes: In stories, myths and legends, the public house or inn has often been a place where the narrative arc is disrupted, where meetings with strangers lead to unforeseen twists and turns in the weaving of the tale. Not so long ago, the Steamship was a pub, and before that an inn. We invite you to our evening of soup and stories where we’ll be breaking bread, setting the soup to simmer, and listening to a host of songsters, spoken word artists, poets and storytellers. In what used to be the main room of the pub, where many tall tales were once told, we invite you to pull up a stool, listen, and maybe even tell a story or two of your own...

facilities: Family activities during open house festival

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The Steamship was built in 1885 by architect Edward Brown of Spitalfields, although there are traces of a pub with the same name dating back to 1842.

It served as public house up until the early 2000s and we can only begin to imagine the array of costumers it must have had throughout the centuries! Merchants, pirates, dockworkers, people from all over the world have formed a neighbourhood which has borne witness to the British Empire's global exploits. The legacy of the colonial era lies in the streets surrounding the pub: Cotton Street, Nutmeg Lane, East India Dock Road... the list goes on.
 
Slowly the Docklands could no longer serve as a port: cargo ships grew too big to enter the docks. The former industrial area became the site of post war council housing and, a few decades later, these same houses were to be overshadowed by Canary Wharf. Next to its skyscrapers, a new wave of gentrification is taking over Balfron Tower and Robin Hood Gardens - historical social housing complexes which for their time, were revolutionary in their vision of a new and inclusive urban design.

Since its closure as a pub, The Steamship was first under a property guardianship scheme, then briefly became a squat, and since 2017, it has been a Project Space... or at least that's how we like to call it.

factsheet.heading: The Steamship Project Space
paragraphs: Not much has changed in the outlook of the building, the facade is the same as Edward Brown envisioned it.

Inside the building however, there are twelve artists from different backgrounds and practices, who live and work in this former pub. But our community of artists that constitute The Steamship PS is much bigger, making it a space always open to those looking to experiment and create work from the grassroots up.

As well as providing living and working space The Steamship Project Space has been supporting local emerging artists by organising events like art exhibitions, performance nights, theatre events, art workshops and film nights.
